CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The Agave Facility has safety features to manage potential hazards, contain and control a spill, detect a release, mitigate the consequences of a release and ensure the continued safe operation of the process.  These features include:
 1.  Monitoring and control with SCADA software.
 2.  Management, surveillance and control by trained onsite operational personnel.
 3.  Offsite monitoring and shutdown capabilities.
 4.  Hazardous chemical and gas level detection, alarm and automatic shutdown.

Containment and control features include:
 1.  Pressure relief devices to avoid over pressurizing.
 2.  Valves that control and/or isolate part or all of the process.
 3.  Interlocks and shutdowns for specific process parameters.
 4.  Curbing and/or diking to contain spills.

Active and Passive mitigation features:
 1.  Fire extinguishing equipment.
 2.  Established and documented emergency procedures.
 3.  Coordination with emergency responders.
 4.  Personal Protective Equipment and other safety equipment.

Management of Change
The Agave Facility has a comprehensive system to manage changes to all covered processes. This system requires that changes such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including operating conditions of the process), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to (1) determine that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, equipment information, and operating procedures are updated prior to incorporating these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel and affected contractors are provided any necessary training on the change.

Incident Investigation
The Agave Facility promptly investigates all incidents related to a covered process that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the factors that may have led to the incident, and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to Agave management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the recommendations. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during future and revalidated PHAs.

Mechanical Integrity
The elements of the Agave Facility Mechanical Integrity program are periodic tests and inspections, regular maintenance, trained personnel, work order systems, written procedures and  record keeping.  The program includes pressure vessels, atmospheric tanks, piping, relief and vent systems, process equipment, pumps, compressors as well as dehydration, hot oil and flaring equipment.

Maintenance personnel receive training including:
(1) an overview of the process, 
(2) safety and health hazards, 
(3) applicable maintenance procedures, 
(4) emergency procedures, and 
(5) work practices to help verify that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner.

Written inspection, testing and maintenance procedures provide that work is performed properly, and serve as a basis for training maintenance personnel in their assigned duties

Inspections and tests are performed to ensure that the equipment functions as intended and to establish a baseline for future monitoring. If a deficiency is identified that presents a safety concern, Agave personnel will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service.

Safe Work Practices

Contractors
The Agave Facility uses contractors to supplement its workforce for construction, maintenance and testing.  To verify that these contractors meet the safety and workplace standard, Agave personnel complete contractor evaluation forms at regular intervals.  These completed forms are evaluated by safety and management to determine compliance with the established policies, procedures and guidelines.  Contractors must maintain an acceptable score on these reviews to continue working at the facility.  In addition, the Safety Group reviews the contractor's written safety program, its implementation, training and accident history to ensure that it complies with the Agave Facility requirements.

The Agave facility provides contractors with:
 1.  A process overview
 2.  Safety orientation and ensures their understanding through testing.
 3.  Information about health and safety hazards.
 4.  Emergency evacuation procedures and mustering location.
 5.  All site specific safe work practices.

Training
Agave has implemented a comprehensive training program to prepare potential process operators to safely and efficiently operate the facility.  Operators-in-training are taught an overview of the process, operating procedures, lock out/tag out, consequences of deviation, emergency response and operating parameters.  After an initial training phase, each candidate is paired with a senior operator for a minimum of 90 days to learn process specific tasks and duties.  The operator-in-training may remain paired with a senior operator beyond the 90 days if necessary, until they can demonstrate enough proficiency to satisfy the Operations Foreman.  The final step in becoming an operator is passing a rigorous written exam called the Compressor Operator Signoff (COS).  After all these requirements have been met, the new Operator can work independently.  New Operators are monitored by the Operations foremen.  Education is an ongoing process and as such, all operators receive periodic training related to their job duties.  In addition to all of this instruction, formal refresher training is conducted every three years. Each step of the operator training course is documented and becomes a permanent part of the employee's file.

Process Hazard Analysis
The Agave Facility uses the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) findings to improve operating procedures, consequence of deviations and mechanical integrity.  The PHA systematically evaluates each process for potential hazards and then recommends change where needed.  These PHAs are revalidated every five years.

The PHA team is selected from management and employees.   Members are chosen based on their knowledge in operating and maintaining the process and engineering expertise.

The Agave Facility considers a variety of factors when conducting the PHA using a combination of the What if and HAZOP methods for evaluating potential hazards.  Some of the factors considered are:
 1.  Process Safety Information (PSI).
 2.  Cause and Effects.
 3.  Human factors.
 4.  Public health.
 5.  Environmental factors.
 6.  Safeguards in place.
 7.  Facility siting.
 8.  Incidents, accidents and near miss reports.
 9.  Management of Change (MoC) information.
10.  All previous PHAs.

The results of the PHAs are published and made available to all personnel.  The PHA follow-up items are promptly addressed based on their priority ranking.  The responses to the PHA recommendations are tracked until they are resolved.  Agave retains these records of previous PHAs.

 4.  Directly involved employees in the establishment of maintenance and operating procedures.
 5.  Sought input for training, both in subject matter and timing from employees.
 6.  Trained all employees in the Management of Change (MOC) process.
 7.  Included employee input in the Process Safety Information (PSI).

The Agave Facility actively encourages employee participation in all aspects of operation and safety.  The result is a more invested group of personnel and an ever increasing accident prevention awareness.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES
EOG Resources has a longstanding commitment to public welfare and worker safety.  EOG addresses accidental release prevention through four factors:  design, training, operating parameters and regular maintenance.  Through design efforts, we have limited the public exposure.  Through training, we have prepared our personnel to respond effectively.  Limiting the operating parameters reduces the stress on process equipment.  And regular maintenance serves to prolong equipment life as well as discover potential problems before they become a safety issue.

Should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur, EOG personnel will evaluate the  conditions, take actions within their capabilities to minimize the risk and notify the appropriate outside agencies,

FACILITY BACKGROUND INFORMATION
Agave Amine Treating Facility is located in a rural area in La Salle County, Texas.  This facility is a natural gas amine treatment  plant.

Inlet Compression will boost the inlet gas pressure from 850 PSIG up to 1,250 PSIG. The inlet gas will then be treated with Methyldiethanolamine (MDEA) to remove excess Carbon Dioxide (CO2) from 4 mol% down to ppm levels. The sweet gas will then be dehydrated to meet a 7 lb/mmscf H2O pipeline spec. Sweet dehydrated gas will be used for fuel for onsite compression, heaters, and electrical generators. Acid gas from the amine plant will be sent to a CO2 Vent Stack with connections to accommodate future acid gas compression for offsite acid gas injection.
